## Budget from Kulturbryggan grant

We received funding from Kultubryggan to start Tau, a space for creators of participatory art and culture. Total budget for the Transforma project was 2.7 million SEK for two years, of which 1 million was the grant and the other 1.7 million were income different sorts of memberships, courses and events in collaboration with other activities in the house that Tau would share. Out of those 2.7 million, we budgeted 500 thousand (excl. VAT) for investments in tools and machinery. However, even though we got a grant of 1 million, we can't spend the entire 400 thousand all at once. This is because it was a part of a budget of a total of 2.7 million, which also includes  income from the Blivande memberships and events. We need to mind our liquidity, as we have rent to pay every month.

# Average monthly investment budget until May 2020

I have come up with the following spending schedule for Tau. These are *average* numbers, and we can concentrate the finances a bit more than 30k monthly. If we don't spend anything one month, we can spend 60k  the next month, but we can't really pull off spending 90k in a single month. We should really try to even it out if we can. 

Some expensive machines (50k+) we will have to lease or pay in instalments. When the time comes to buy a CNC mill for example, I will probably go to the bank and sign a contract to lease it.

| Month  | SEK    |
|--------|--------|
| Jan 19 |      |
| Feb 19 | 30.000 |
| Mar 19 | 30.000 |
| Apr 19 | 30.000 |
| May 19 | 30.000 |
| Jun 19 | 30.000 |
| Jul 19 |        |
| Aug 19 |        |
| Sep 19 | 30.000 |
| Oct 19 | 30.000 |
| Nov 19 | 30.000 |
| Dec 19 |        |
| Jan 20 | 30.000 |
| Feb 20 | 30.000 |
| Mar 20 | 30.000 |
| Apr 20 | 30.000 |
| May 20 | 30.000 |

Note that I'm assuming we don't buy anything in July and August, and that we are not expecting to buy anything in December, which is because it looks like December might be a frugal month before we get the next annual payment from the Node in January. Of course, this may change if we recruit members to Beta and Tau faster than we are currently predicting. Likewise, if we get more surplus than we are currently expecting due to faster than expected growth of our revenue stream, we can invest more than the 480k we currently have planned.

In case we really feel the need to make a large investment after the summer, I could also look into lumping our budget for the fall and 2020 together in a single sum and going to the bank for an investment loan that we'd pay back within a year. Interest on that should not be too bad.

## What does this mean for the coming two months?

We have currently budgeted around 60k for outfitting the wood workshop (@Jan_vL, @hampus, @juliaa, @LinearMilk, @Sero, @dsandber, @annielocke ). This lays a good foundation. Buying the digital router @dsandber suggested is also possible, as long as we can pay him back in instalments over the coming year. We also want to get started on outfitting the textile workshop (@AnjM, @brooks) soon.

By being a bit smart, we could for example spend our money this way in the coming three months:
* Spend 30k in cash in February on Blocket items, tools bought in Germany.
* Spend 30k in February invoiced in stores where we have credit, giving us 30 days to pay (using March budget).
* Spend another 30k invoiced in March or on our company credit card, using April budget.

We would then have another 60k to spend in the spring when people start building art for The Borderland, Burning Man and other participatory events.

'Sup! We had a great and inspiring meeting about marketing for Blivande on Thursday with @SofiaAnner, @Sero, @hampus, @Simpykatt and @ben.english. Time to really put this place on the MAP by showing how amazing the space and community are. 

We think the best way to do that is through **short video clips**, so that we bring our energy into the posts and also so that people see and feel more of the physical spaces than you can capture with a still photo. 

And we're hoping you can help! One of the "types" of post we will make is called **"What are you up to right now?"**. It's a way of showing our personalities and the things we do. 

**Here's how to help us by making videos for our social media:**
- Get out your phone and call someone by their name with the question. E.g. "Hey Sofia, what are you up to right now?"
- The video clip should be 30s-1m long
- Get consent from the person before you film, or at least before you send it to me
- Please film in portrait for now, and try and keep the phone relatively still and smooth as you move it
- Bonus points for cool framing
- Send to me. Not sure if you can do that here. Or 0706817331/kim.gajraj@gmail.com
- The winner of "best post" will be decided each week by how many engagements the post gets. Lots of glory involved in this title obvs.

I'm using Autodesk Fusion 360 CAD & CAM. It's a bit to learn, but the CAM module is actually pretty good. There's also the more primitive [Carbide Create](https://carbide3d.com/carbidecreate/) if you mostly want to do 2D stuff. I've tried small engravings with a 6€ 3.2 mm-shaft engraving tool, it worked fine even in tool steel (with low depth, obviously).

The machine controller is GRBL 1.1f, the standard grbl-postprocessor works fine. As a g-code sender, I've used both the manufacturers [Carbide Motion](https://carbide3d.com/carbidemotion/) and [cncjs](https://cnc.js.org/), both work.

Thanks @SimianSon for giving us more nuance, and also for the creative work you're doing with the workshops.

These kind of creative solutions as you're discussing with Free Flow is exactly the kinds that I was aiming for with the original posted guidelines in this thread. I'm very happy to see that this work has started.

I agree with the mental health perspective you bring up. Noden supplies an important civic service to the society, and putting our operations to a halt should not be done lightly. I had to think this through the whole day yesterday to balance the perspectives against each other.

With that said, I want to clarify that it is not FHM's recommendations we're following with the proposed temporary close-down, but the local recommendations from Region Stockholm. Earlier this year the Regions didn't have a mandate to take local action, and instead the rules where applied for the whole country by FHM. The new laws passed give us better granularity to have local recommendations where the Covid spreading is as worst. Unfortunately, Stockholm is one of those regions now. 

My proposed decision was to halt the operation (all workshops etc) during the period up until 19th November, and during this time work on guidelines for how to better prepare our workshops, so we can open up again with better prepared for the tough situation will most certainly have during the long dark winter when Noden is needed the most.

Since this is a strong recommendation from the local authorities, I don't see that we can avoid following them. We need to cut down the infectious spreading rate, and it's going to take a toll on all of us. But if we do it, then hopefully it is only for three weeks and not for the whole winter.

Once again, I want to encourage you to continue the creative work in finding safety precautions that can keep the workshops going, it will come to good use sooner if not later!

Together with the Edgeryders [Brussels Reef project](http://thereef.brussels/) and Fondazione per l’Innovazione Urbana in Bologna, we have sent an application to Climate KIC to fund an expo on "ecological futurism" and "solarpunk" in the fall of 2020. If we get it, I will update you further on what it means, but the idea would be to invite the community to build and create together. Here is a summary of the application.

______

Our expo is a curated, accessible, collection of open source solutions for green-and-social urban living. By “solutions” we mean technologies, social arrangements, business models and aesthetic design patterns. This exploration happens in three sites in Brussels, Bologna, and Stockholm. We aspire to develop this collaboration into a global network of social-and-green urban spaces.

Behavioral change can be a powerful force in decarbonizing the economy. But most people see it as buying small environmental benefits with large personal sacrifices. This is a hard sell and has failed to happen at scale. A city is not only made of streets, buildings and urban infrastructure. A city is all these things, plus the knowledge and the skills embedded in its local community. The latter enables the maintenance, adaptation, development, and improvement of physical infrastructure. That's why:

1. we do not aim for incremental change. Instead, we rewire urban life into a different configuration. Helped by an enabling space, people's carbon footprint shrink naturally.
2. we see behavioral change as something communities, not individuals, do. We harness humans’ evolved ability for working in groups and put it to the service of radical behavioral change.
3. we focus on people who already aspire to behavioral change. 

The Reef rewires the city's software towards “green” and “resilient”. It makes an alternative way of living visible, achievable, and aspirational. It teaches how to live a harmonious urban life that acknowledges climate change, and takes charge for it: this means adaptation, leading to resilience (microclimate improvements, insulation), also mitigation, leading to emission cuts (energy efficiency, circular economy, urban agriculture and so on).

In Stockholm, Blivande brings art and culture to the table, supporting a narrative of hope and opportunity in the face of climate emergency. Blivande is also situated in the harbor of Stockholm, which is undergoing one of the largest urban developments in Europe, Stockholm Royal Seaport. In the next decade, 12,000 dwellings and 35,000 workplaces will be built there, as part of the Clinton Climate Initiative. As part of the Reef Network, Blivande can better inspire the efforts at Stockholm Royal Seaport with new hopeful narratives of how community-based innovation is an important factor to meet the global emergency.

@brooks and I had a productive discussion today. I'll segment it for clarity. 

**MACHINES**
We agreed that the Husqvarna overlocker is not sufficient to cover an actual overlocker machine. 
Counting all other expenses, we have an extra 3-4K available within our 30K budget. 
A regular (we could search for a second hand here too @brooks ?)  machine costs 6K. As mentioned, we could source a second hand one. 
There is another machine option called Babylock, but it is twice as expensive.
 In the long term it would be very-times-10 suited for us because it adjusts to the thickness of a fabric when there are multiple users/different projects and is much easier to thread: the advantage is that a regular overlocker is difficult to thread for a regular user and if someone messes up or say, uses a very different fabric thickness after somebody else, it might stop production for that day as someone would have to re-thread it. And that is not an easy task. 
 I think perhaps the Babylock could be a future investment, and for now we can buy either a used or new Overlocker (6K) which means we exceed our budget by 2K. In some time, we can sell the overlocker and buy a Babylock. Prices are outlined in the Excel doc. that I made. @hugi, please advise. 

**COSMETICS**
 We need to make this room look cool and magical, so that people want to come back and feel inspired doing their projects. 
 We want to make this room operational mid-May (explained in later segment) so we really need more members to step up and help out with painting and decorating. 
 I'm thinking cacti on the window ledges. Because why not. I also saw a peculiar colour from a photo showed to me by a colleague when he was visiting a castle in North India.

 Really lacking extra hands here.

**DONATIONS**

 If we make a list of items people might have, would it be possible to reach out to the community and ask? 

**RECRUIT AND MOBILISE**
As above mentioned, we need a few more people to help out with the set-up, if possible.
We want to launch the space mid-May. Reason being:

Posting here, same as in other laser topic, reading both will give cerebral hemorrhaging

Hi! 

Yeah, I am habitually over my head in diverse projects and to add to that, a bit broken. Been having some health problems, nothing severe but having me unable to get around to doing stuff.

Last I was there we had an introductory course, but those attending probably needed more hands-on examples done, and help along their first solo projects to feel sure about using the machine. I was a bit rusty, and learning by doing is the best way. Its hard to condense and convey methods learned/developed over years of use. 

So, to get cracking again, we first need to work out the issues with the machine, since it has not been running properly. In the spirit of learning together, and me being long-winded, I'm gonna type out the trouble shooting here in the forum. Hopefully we can resolve it faster this way too.

**Olle reports it drops significantly in power after running for a while. There are many factors that can reduce power.** 
Most are due to regular use of the machine, and therefore are addressed in regular maintenance. *Smoke residue on lens/mirrors/laser tube business end, Poor fume evacuation.*
Other factors are incorrect settings.
*power/speed setting in software overridden/reduced in machine settings, incorrect focus*
Also mirror calibration can be off, and the laser tube degrades as a whole with use, etc..

**BUT...**
Intermittent power loss, that occurs after running a while, is probably because one of two hardware bits being at the end of its life. The laser tube power supply, which brings the voltage upp to a cosy ~20KV DC and exites the CO2 gas in the tube to produce the energy. If this one is old and tired it can have reduced effect as it is working and getting warm.

The other probable cause is insufficient cooling. Then laser tube is dependent cooled by a separate water cooling system, composed of a circulation pump and compressor radiator thingy.  This one has been thru a lot, from running dry, having its temp probe severed, being fed way to rich glycol blend and then some.. Also the system was hard to flush after the move. Thermostat regulating the effect seemed a bit wonky too...

**To sum up all that; the next step here is to run a test and measure temps on the cooling water, and compare it to effect loss.**
If Olle or anyone else tech savvy feel up to doing this it would speed up matters, as I could get on sorting the necessary spares.

As for time for repairs and a date for a workshop, I can make my way over and spend some time week after next, but even better if the errors could be diagnosed before then.

If you made it this far, gold star! :)

What kind of “traditional” deployment setup are you referring to? I’m curious.
[/quote]

Not really sure yet :D , input or thoughts about this would be great. But in an ideal world it would be nice to have something that could unify deployment for realities, dreams, pretix etc. If that involves Docker and AWS, Azure or Heroku, I don't really know. I was recently recommended [dokku](https://github.com/dokku/dokku) which looks interesting. 

Vercel is "serverless" and on the one hand I really like the platform, its pretty simple, easy to get going and you don't pay for servers that are running but not doing anything, but there are some limitations and trade-offs. You need to handle databases somewhere else etc. And it feels like a bit of a lock-in too.

Would be nice to be able to easily add something like [imaginary](https://github.com/h2non/imaginary) for image processing and store images in something like an AWS bucket, to not rely on external image processing services like cloudinary for example. I guess we can do that today too, but it would be nice to not have everything scattered around in different places :)

BUT we should still have the meeting tonight. We can discuss this further there, plus talk to the venue people. And IF we will be able to be at the same venue at a later date, it's great if more people have seen it.

Layout 2 is really great in my mind and close to the original vision which really helps since we don't have to do so many changes that are not already pre-approved. It’s also much less work.

I would suggest to tweak it a bit however and keep the E room where it is. It’s a bit underutilized atm but I think that will change, especially if more people realize that they can actually use it also for non-electronic work when it’s otherwise empty.

Assuming we get a container for storage outside of Tau we could rather remove the glass wall on the current storage room instead and create more open workspaces there while getting rid of the corridor feel. For flex spaces to complement the nearby montage room for example.

The question how to best move and where to integrate the textile room is a remaining issue. The way I see it it stands between three alternatives:

* Creating a textile part of the expanded montage room.
* Combining it with the E room (not ideal).
* Having it be part of the new open space (at the cost of less flex spots there).

[quote="Simon, post:18, topic:1053"]
ett tillvägagångssätt där vem som helst, när som helst kan gå in och kommentera och ha åsikter mitt i en kreativ process.
Jag kan helt ärligt inte tänka mig någon annan stans där konstnärer mitt under ett skapande skulle gå med på detta.
[/quote]

Det här är en väldigt intressant betraktelse för jag tror att den sätter fingret på en slags kulturkrock eller åtminstone friktion mellan olika typer av organisationsformer- och kulturer. För mig som hållit på med Borderland och andra participatoriska events och communities i 10 år (och därmed är helt marinerad och till viss del hemmablind i det) så faller det mig naturligt att *utgångspunkten* är att kreativa processer generellt sett är öppna för input och feedback. Eftersom det (i min erfarenhet och tolkning) finns en sån tydlig uppsida i att välkomna den kollektiva intelligensen och kreativiteten. Givetvis förutsätter detta ett visst minimum av den tidigare nämnda fingertoppskänslan.

Sedan är det här alltid kontextuellt och individuellt beroende på situation. Men jag tror att våra "base lines"/nollpunkter är ganska olika här. Och jag gissar att Hugi, Linnéa och andra här med liknande bakgrund fungerar delvis lika. Min teori är också att det är något som ofta gradvis "växer på en" med tiden och att man lär sig hantera nackdelarna bättre allteftersom. Our mileage may and will vary though!

Sedan ska det också sägas att det finns ingenting som säger att man behöver acceptera eller "rätta sig" efter den här kulturen för att agera som konstnär inom participatoriska sammanhang. Det finns gott om tongivande och mkt uppskattade konstnärer som arbetar utifrån ett mer klassiskt individualistiskt arbetssätt även på BL, Burning Man och inom lajvscenen etc. 

På ett personligt plan vill jag också poängtera att jag själv nu känner ett sug efter att inte längre "go full participatory" efter att ha jobbat så mycket för det kollektiva och med möjliggörande under så många år (Secret Island Nation, Borderland, Afterglow, Urban Burn, Ascension, Noden och nu Blivande). Jag känner ett behov av att uttrycka mig mer direkt och personligt, utan att ta hänsyn till andra människor lika mycket. I also use [72220](http://www.sni2007.scb.se/snihierarki2007.asp?sniniva=5&snikod=72200), which is for generic b2b consulting (business dev, org dev, hr, etc).

I was genuinely looking forward to this and I'm sad to see that it's been cancelled. :pensive:
I fully understand why though. This is the second time in a row that Peder's initiative ends up being left hanging in the air to eventually fall to the ground from a lack of response. This is a worrying signal as to the current vitality of our community (or rather community in the making). 

I'm also not without fault in this as I had promised to mail out a reminder about this event to all of our members. Something I ended up forgetting while trying to tend to some of the fires of tonight's party. I'm sorry about that Peder! 

For various reasons our efforts towards long-term community building (this dinner being an example of what we set out to arrange at least once a month) has been temporarily set aside to give focus to more short-term pressing issues. This is of course not sustainable as the community is the very raison d'être of Blivande, which our success or failure ultimately rests on. 

There are plenty of other co-working places (or makerspaces) to choose from if what we have to offer is not more than just that. Luckily enough we do have much more to offer and great synergetic evenings like that of yesterday provide a glimpse into that. But we need more of it and have plenty of nurturing and nudging to do ahead of us.

Fundamentally though we very much **need your help** in this if we are to succeed with this experiment. We all have to show up, in however way or form that we want to or can. Not every day or every time, but regularly. Here online yes, but more importantly physically in the house. And especially when someone is taking a clear initiative to create something for our collective benefit!

This is especially true for Tau which is and have always been a collaborative bottoms-up project in the vein of Borderland and Urban Burn, co-created by its members from start to finish. It won't happen unless you make it so as a community working together. The ones of us directly involved with Blivande will do our very best to help facilitate but we can't do it alone. And even if we could it would defeat the whole purpose. Today I spent a couple of hours putting in new door handles for the textile and future painting room and clearing out some of the clutter while Linnéa vaccuumed. And Joannis big PA now stands in the much improved techno temple! Things are progressing, slowly but steadily. But we need more hands on deck if we are to have a functional space before summer. 

Much hangs in the balance this first fragile year. Let's all help push this thing in the direction of joy, purpose and community! 

P.S. 
You're all invited to come and have dinner with Hugi, Linnéa and I on Monday evening at 19. Hope to see some you there despite the short notice. There will be a potluck dinner announced shortly for a later date. 

Also the whole of next weekend the house will be full with 33 great people from all over Europe attending the Co-creative Leadership Development Program. Good opportunity to come in for some work and then hang out in the evening.

I have made a template for us to better understand the emphasis of the Kulturbryggan application process. It's a RealtimeBoard where I have also included the funding criteria and translations into English. [Use this template](https://realtimeboard.com/app/board/o9J_kyZMAgw=/) to structure and write your application, then [apply at the Kulturbryggan website](https://www.konstnarsnamnden.se/logga-in-e-tjanst).

Remember that you can include one year (or more) of membership at Studio Beta in your application, which also gives you access to Studio Tau. If you already have a membership, consider funding a Beta membership for a collaborator you want to work with, or 2-3 Tau memberships for people you want to have working with you. You can also include funding to rent the downstairs space for you opening or the big Tau room if you need a lot of space for some duration of time. Blivande needs members to keep the lights and to keep investing in the space.

Does it need to withstand the elements or multiple installations? If not, paper also offers a cheap, warm and simple way to diffuse light for led since you do not need to care about the temperature and in every half-decent art shop you can choose between many different kinds, sizes and weights. You can bring a light in a shoebox to the shop and check the effect. But it breaks very very easily, only for installations that are kind of out of reach for people to collide with. Otherwise, I used thin (around 1 mm)  white HIP plastic sheets which are also used for vacuum-forming. You can easily cut those, even by hand and glue or screw them on nicely, and you can even make them go around round corners or bend slightly with the frame.

We had a meeting tonight discussing the current state of Tau. @AnjM took some notes. 

#Studio Tau – Summary of Intentions

* Tau will unfold in 2 phases. We discussed practicalities around this. More about these two phases in the [first Studio Tau info thread](https://edgeryders.eu/t/studio-tau-what-is-it-and-how-do-i-sign-up/9199).

* Tau will always be an open ended collaborative space with shared responsibility.
	* Period 1 till October 1st: Experimental stage, figuring out what  equipment and needs should be met. Not all spaces will be set yet. 
	* From October 1st, intention for things to be more set, rooms more specialised and no 'private' spaces apart from Artist in Residence.
* Intention is cross-collaborative (encourage members to run workshops, initiatives, etc.)
*  Effective time use. Maximise use of space.
*  BETA: 32 members with access to Bata and Tau
*  TAU: 32 members only Tau access   
*  Model is flexible and experimental in its initial stages. 
* Discussion of business plan and sustaining the space economically/long-term is for another meeting: to be discussed in another platform and occasion if there is enough interest.

## Studio Tau Communication Chanels
* Facebook is unfavourable for multiple reasons.
* EDGERYDERS FORUM: suggestion for slow/intermediate discussions, longer span discussions, long-term planning.
* SLACK for shorter immediate communication (forum ineffective here.)
* SLACK is not for decision making but for immediate communication. EDGERYDERS forum is better for decisions, planning and slower long-form discussions.
* Long-term decisions and communication will be recorded via forum.
* FORUM is for transparency of actions/updates. 
* BLIVANDE website in progress will be connected to the Tau forum. Different methods to promote events via these connected platforms/websites.

# Other points

* Fire Alarm: We recently accidentally triggered the fire alarm. It might become a problem with the automatic alarm. Costs of response is extremely expensive. We need to find solution.

So together with author and philosopher Luis de Miranda I'm organizing some events that will take place in house on Fri May 17th (possibly also the 18th). It's a combination of a book launch and a workshop in how to create neon signs. 

The book is called **[Being and Neonness](https://mitpress.mit.edu/books/being-and-neonness-translation-and-content-revised-augmented-and-updated-edition-luis-de-miranda)** and explores both the literal and the figurative history of neon, using it as a metaphor for the 20th century and the evolution of postmodernism. Or something along those lines. I haven't actually read it yet. :slight_smile:

In any case, the book has just been translated to English for MIT Press so as a celebration of this Luis has invited Nasser, one of Europe's last remaining neon glass-blowers. Nasser will lead a paid workshop for anyone interested in trying out this classic but now all but extinct craft. One goal of the workshop will be to produce a Blivande sign that we can later mount on the building!
We could probably create a special one for Studio Tau as well... 

Is anyone here interested in being part of either the neon workshop or the whole thing? Would be great with more people involved in organizing the events!

I think it's the other way around actually. Container is also better long-term, assuming that what you mean with full-blown can still fit inside. Our hope is that Tau will eventually outgrow the current building and find a dedicated and more industrial shell somewhere else in Frihamnen. Having a big part of it then mobile and circumventing hotworks bureaucracy etc (and not having carved up the facade at Blivande) is great.

Being mobile we can rent it out (won't happen much but perhaps once a year or less) or bring it with us to festivals and what not. It's not at all lots of work to move it, it's a standard shipping container after all. It does cost money though, and 40' containers require more specialized/rare trucks than 20'. But basically it's just about money. Moving it to BL would cost around 15k-20k SEK one way. Maybe a bit less. 

I had an offer for 11k moving a 20' container from Axel to BL last year. It got much more expensive in the end but that was only due to us having to pay for delaying the departure since it wasn't ready to go at the arranged pickup time. This wouldn't be the case here.
